newsitem.title: UK: Greenpeace ends Atlantic oil rig protest.
newsitem.headline: Greenpeace ends Atlantic oil rig protest.

text.p: The environmental protest group Greenpeace said on Sunday it was ending its occupation of a British Petroleum oil rig in the north Atlantic.
Up to seven activists had boarded the Stena Dee floating platform over the past week as part of a campaign to stop new oil exploration in the area.
Greenpeace wants to stop oil exploration on the grounds that burning even existing reserves of fossil fuels will cause irreversible climate change.
Greenpeace said its personnel and equipment were being taken off the rig onto the group's ship, MV Greenpeace.
It denied that its campaign against the Stena Dee, which is heading for the Foinavon oil field about 100 miles north of Scotland, had ended in failure.
Greenpeace UK's Deputy Executive Director, Chris Rose, said safety could no longer be guaranteed if the occupation continued.
"Activists are exhausted and our equipment and material is at its limits after operating continuously in the northeast Atlantic since April," he said in a statement.

Greenpeace has also been blocking an Alantic Richfield rig off the Alaskan coast to keep it away from a field in the Arctic Beaufort Sea. A U.S. federal judge on Friday ordered the activists to stay outside a moving safety buffer around the mobile rig.
The blockades, aimed at fighting global warming, are part of Greenpeace's most ambitious campaign yet against the oil industry.
British Petroleum had served writs against the Greenpeace protesters, ordering them to stop their occupation of the Stena Dee.
But the group vowed to continue its campaign against fossil fuels and challenged BP to make solar power affordable for ordinary consumers.
